没有什么比相互冲突的激励措施更能激怒管理理论家了。 （如果一个激动的管理理论家的想法毁了你的早餐，抱歉。）他们思考财务动机——比如个人奖金计划可能对团队合作产生的不利影响。他们针对股东和代表他们行事的高管之间的利益竞争撰写大量研究报告和书籍。

加州大学圣地亚哥分校的 Achyuta Adhvaryu 以及密歇根大学的 Emir Murathanoglu 和 Anant Nyshadham 发表的一篇新论文为这个问题提供了新的线索。它表明激励冲突并不总是与财务有关，甚至不同级别的管理人员之间也可能发生冲突。在此过程中，它强调了一个备受嘲笑的群体应该得到更加认真的对待。

作者研究了印度最大的服装制造商之一 Shahi Exports 中层管理人员的决定。该公司拥有大约 70 家工厂，由多个裁剪师、裁缝师和整理师组成的团队生产服装。在他们的研究中，学者们追踪了哪些团队主管被自己的经理推荐参加软技能培训，然后研究了该培训对生产力和保留率的影响。

他们的发现很奇怪。平均而言，培训有效。与对照组相比，其主管参加过该课程的团队的生产力得到了显着提高。但这些进步的分布并不均匀。中层管理者极力推荐其主管接受培训的团队，其生产力并未得到提高；好处主要集中在不太推荐的主管身上。保留的模式则相反：受到经理强烈推荐的主管随后的辞职率大幅下降，而不太推荐的主管则几乎没有变化。

阿德瓦尤先生等人研究了对这种奇怪模式的各种解释，并得出结论认为，这反映了一种深思熟虑的计算：经理们提名了那些他们认为存在逃亡风险的主管。这并不一定符合公司高层领导的利益。但这确实符合中层管理人员的利益，他们承担着填补空缺主管和培训新主管的重担。简而言之，失去工人让他们的生活变得更加困难。对他们来说，保留比生产力更重要。

除了激励很重要这个古老的教训之外，这篇论文还提供了三个教训。首先，只要权力下放，就会出现代理问题。去中心化的组织通常很有意义，但它也有引入多层利益竞争的风险。时任加州大学伯克利分校的英格丽德·海格勒 (Ingrid Haegele) 最近发表的另一篇论文发现，一家大型制造公司的德国经理试图为自己的团队囤积最优秀的工人。当管理者自己即将调任新职位时，他们就没有动力阻止优秀员工跳槽。海格勒女士发现，在这些暂时无私的时期，员工申请内部晋升的数量增加了一倍多。

第二个教训是，中层管理者更值得尊重，而不是嘲笑。学者们观察到的这种行为是可能的，因为这些管理者拥有宝贵的私人信息：他们知道谁正在考虑离开公司以及谁值得保留。角落办公室和董事会会议室的人们通常距离实际情况太远，无法获得这种洞察力。

所有这些都意味着，如果激励措施正确，中层管理人员可以对员工的绩效产生巨大的有益影响。 Shahi Exports 的第三个教训是，金钱并不总是问题的根源。其中层管理人员正在提出培训建议，以避免因更高的客户流失而带来额外的工作。

这可能会让他们听起来很懒。事实上，他们都面临着一个共同的问题。 《权力到中层》是一本即将出版的关于中层管理者的书，作者是麦肯锡的三名顾问艾米丽·菲尔德 (Emily Field)、布莱恩·汉考克 (Bryan Hancock) 和比尔·沙宁格 (Bill Schaninger)。它认为，缺乏时间和资源困扰着世界各地这些不幸的灵魂。本书对 700 名中层管理人员进行的一项调查发现，他们每周花一整天的时间处理行政任务。更换优秀员工从来都不是一件有趣的事，但如果经理已经空手而归，那就更糟糕了。你不需要成为一名理论家才能解决这个问题。 ■

; Thu, 29 Jun 2023 14:38:41 GMT /内容/s22pt586j8qje5ne5d9cbe3s4ja9c0ga https://www.economist.com/business/2023/06/29/the-potential-and-the-plight-of-the-middle-manager Meet the world’s most flirtatious sovereign-wealth fund

2016 年，我们的专栏作家在利雅得，当时身着长袍和凉鞋的穆罕默德·本·萨勒曼宣布了他的 2030 年愿景，旨在结束王储所说的沙特王国对石油的依赖。沙特阿拉伯事实上的统治者谈到出售世界上最大的石油公司沙特阿美公司的股票，为价值2万亿美元的巨型主权财富基金（ SWF ）提供资金，投资于各种非石油行业。他将成为其主席、捐助者和策划者。这是令人兴奋的事情，尽管其中一些在像沙特阿拉伯这样墨守成规的独裁国家中听起来有些精神错乱。最引人注目的事情发生在后来，一名宫廷官员邀请熊彼特去一家咖啡馆。年轻男女不戴头巾地坐着，公然调情。打破规则的气氛非常热烈。

如今，沙特主权财富基金，即公共投资基金（ PIF ），正在成为穆罕默德亲王梦想的巨人。其资产价值已飙升至 7000 亿美元，拥有 1,400 多名员工，全球形象不断提升，并且像那些年轻的咖啡馆居民一样，它也发现了公开调情的乐趣。无论是彻底改变高尔夫运动、收购欧洲足球名流、押注明星视频游戏公司、白手起家建立一家航空公司还是将阿斯顿·马丁转向电动化， pif都无法停止策划一项又一项引人注目的交易。位于华盛顿特区的智库阿拉伯海湾国家研究所的罗伯特·莫吉尔尼基表示，它以“一切、无处不在、一次性的投资方式”“呼啸而至”。然而，它可能并不像听起来那么混乱。仔细观察，它的投资方式不仅仅是青春期的浮躁。

这要从PIF的任务开始。与许多主权财富基金一样，其目标之一是将国家的石油财富转向全球资产，以实现长期增长。但还需要在国内培育多元化经济，以防石油需求下降。它有积极的扩张计划。它希望到 2025 年积累超过 1 万亿美元的管理资产，到 2030 年至少增加一倍，成为地球上最大的主权财富基金。大部分增长不太可能来自投资回报，尤其是因为其超过三分之二的资产位于沙特阿拉伯。相反，它将需要更多的公共支出，例如 4 月份收到的价值近 800 亿美元的 4% 的沙特阿美股票。可用资金的多少将取决于油价，目前油价远低于去年的高点。

它不仅仅依赖石油。莫吉尔尼基先生指出，如果PIF吸引共同投资者参与其沙特项目，其资产价值可能会增加。这就是其国内战略与国外战略的契合点。它已收购了四支沙特运动队75%的股份，如果将其私有化，可能会吸引更多投资，从而推高其价值。他认为，随着时间的推移，共同投资还可能增加一些工业和旅游大型项目的价值，例如 Neom， PIF 的目标是将其变成沙漠城市乌托邦。这个王国需要游客——包括富有的游客和财力雄厚的投资者——将愿景变成现实。为此， PIF需要让沙特阿拉伯出名。

在这一追求中，最引人注目的策略是运动。无论它是否能实现本世纪的高尔夫大型合并，它现在已经是一个不可忽视的名字。它收购了英超俱乐部纽卡斯尔联队，这是为了实现更大的野心而支付的首付。将王国变成足球强国。吸引像克里斯蒂亚诺·罗纳尔多这样的球员是该战略的一部分，后者最近以 2 亿美元的薪水为沙特队效力。如果这些有影响力的人被用作人物推荐来确保 2030 年FIFA世界杯的主办权，请不要感到惊讶。

此类投资招致了“洗运动”的指控，即利用知名品牌大使来掩盖令人震惊的侵犯人权行为，例如 2018 年沙特阿拉伯出生的《华盛顿邮报》专栏作家贾迈勒·卡舒吉 (Jamal Khashoggi) 被谋杀。然而洗图像也有经济逻辑。卡塔尔通过去年的世界杯展示了瑞银银行的马克斯·卡斯泰利（Max Castelli）所称的举办大型赛事的“声望要素”的价值，无论财务回报如何。体育运动花费的PIF相对较少。然而，它在全球市场上提供了大量的物有所值的关注。

PIF正在进行其他战略投资，这些投资不会引起太大的争议，但也会产生国内影响。值得注意的两个是游戏和清洁能源。 2 月， PIF成为日本游戏公司任天堂的最大外国股东，旗下资产包括动视暴雪 (Activision Blizzard) 和艺电 (Electronic Arts)。它希望将 Neom 变成一个游戏开发中心。至于脱碳，其最大的外国投资之一是对总部位于加州的电动汽车 ( EV ) 制造商 Lucid 的投资。 6月26日，Lucid赢得了一份为英国豪华汽车制造商阿斯顿·马丁提供电动机和电池系统的合同， PIF也是该公司的大股东。不出所料，Lucid 正在沙特阿拉伯建设其第一家海外工厂。

PIF的电动汽车投资既体现了其梦想，也体现了不那么光明的现实。它的一些最大的赌注表现严重不佳。其中包括 Lucid、通过软银愿景基金进行的风险投资，以及其在叫车公司 Uber 中的股份。在国内，其记录也受到玷污。沙特国家银行是其最大的持股之一，3月份因对瑞士信贷银行的不合时宜的投资而损失了一大笔钱。 Neom 等大型项目变得如此宏大，以至于看起来很滑稽（Neom 因居住在这片土地上的 Howeitat 部落的待遇而受到人权审查）。如果投资者被吸引，那将是回报的承诺，而不是波将金村庄的炫目。

揭开面纱

然而， PIF的一大优势是其开放性。数据收集机构 Global SWF的老板迭戈·洛佩兹 (Diego Lopez) 表示，没有哪个主权基金如此公开地宣传其雄心。这无疑是提高穆罕默德亲王勇敢的声誉的一种方式。这也给PIF带来了额外的压力，以确保他的视力不会出现严重错误。 ■

; Thu, 29 Jun 2023 14:38:41 GMT /内容/a13ipkq7g77gl32jo5418o1cbn8pd669 https://www.economist.com/business/2023/06/29/meet-the-worlds-most-flirtatious-sovereign-wealth-fund Why Asia’s super-app companies are stuck in a rut

一位美国科技大亨偶尔会哀叹西方缺乏“超级应用程序”，即提供各种不同服务的多层面在线平台。但全球对该商业模式的兴趣掩盖了亚洲现有超级应用程序面临的困难。

他们最近的表现令人失望（见图表）。总的来说，自 2021 年底以来，新加坡 Sea 和 Grab、韩国 Coupang 和 Kakao、日本 Rakuten 以及印度 Paytm 母公司的市值已下降了约 60%。他们各自通过移动游戏、社交媒体、电子商务、拼车和金融支付等方式赚钱。他们的共同点是渴望将各种服务捆绑在一起，在一个应用程序上相互补充。他们原本希望效仿中国公司，例如腾讯的微信和阿里巴巴的支付宝，这些公司开创了这种商业模式。

但新兴的亚洲超级应用程序却因快速变化的环境而承受着巨大的压力。曾经廉价而充足的资金已经枯竭，使得雄心勃勃的增长计划更难融资。花旗银行的詹姆斯·劳埃德 (James Lloyd) 指出，中国的超级应用程序始于盈利且有吸引力的业务核心（支付宝的电子商务和微信的社交媒体），其他服务都是围绕这些业务构建的。在中国以外，很少有公司能够以类似的方式平衡规模和盈利。

韩国公司 Kakao 最符合这一要求。与大多数亚洲潜在的超级应用程序不同，它已经实现了可靠的盈利。但今年以来，其股价已下跌 8%。由于该公司在本土占据主导地位，因此在国内的进一步增长已经没有空间了。据估计，其网约车部门在韩国的市场份额高达 90%。该公司希望到 2025 年将其国际收入份额从目前的 10% 提高到 30%，但这种全球扩张是有代价的。

在其他公司，资金紧缩激发了盈利野心，这不可避免地以牺牲先前的快速扩张计划为代价。由叫车公司 Gojek 和电子商务公司 Tokopedia 合并而成的印尼超级应用 GoTo 预计将在 6 月 30 日的股东大会上任命前银行家 Patrick Walujo 为首席执行官，在我们发布此内容后。瓦卢霍先生强调，他的目标是让公司盈利。

一家亚洲消费科技公司逆势而上。 Paytm（一款基于数字支付的未来印度超级应用程序）的股价已上涨约 60%。该股仍不到 2021 年 11 月上市后不久达到的历史高点的一半，而且该公司尚未盈利。尽管如此，其股价上涨可能反映出亚洲其他地区的公司所缺乏的东西：一个可以合作的单一、庞大且不断增长的国内市场。这种规模潜力是否足以让 Paytm 实现更可持续的未来还有待观察。

公司使用单一平台向消费者提供多种服务的想法具有直观的吸引力。但经过十多年关于超级应用即将占据主导地位的讨论后，许多亚洲公司仍在努力寻找规模和盈利能力之间的平衡。由于融资成本上涨没有尽头，这些曾经的科技投资者宠儿迅速复苏很难预见。 ■

; Thu, 29 Jun 2023 14:38:40 GMT /内容/lt0jkugopv1dvh025usd7lari5lu2flc https://www.economist.com/business/2023/06/29/why-asias-super-app-companies-are-stuck-in-a-rut South Korea’s government and business are over-close

1993年，李健熙开始了一次世界巡演，盘点他从父亲那里继承的三星公司。当他发现三星的电视机和其他电子产品在货架上闲置时，他决定重塑三星的形象。 “改变一切，除了你的妻子和孩子，”他告诉员工。根据国际投资争端解决中心（ ICSID ）的一项裁决，有一点没有改变，那就是这些构成韩国经济支柱的家族企业集团与政府之间的密切关系。

6 月 20 日，世界银行仲裁论坛裁定，韩国政府因不当干预三星两个子公司的合并而让美国对冲基金埃利奥特投资管理公司 (Elliott Investment Management) 蒙受损失。 2015年三星物产与第一毛织之间的交易被视为确保李在镕及其儿子李在镕顺利继任的一次尝试。拥有三星物产7% 股份的埃利奥特公司（Elliott）反对其股票估值，并发起了一场代理权争夺战，但在持有两家公司股份的韩国国民养老金公社（ NPS ）支持该交易后，埃利奥特公司输掉了这场代理权争夺战。

然而，2016 年，合并时的卫生部长、当时的国家退休金计划负责人文亨杓 (Moon Hyung-pyo) 因向养老金服务部门施压以批准该交易而被起诉。这引发了对三星与政府之间腐败交易的一系列调查，调查显示，李明博曾贿赂时任总统朴槿惠，以帮助其继任。朴女士被弹劾；两人最终都入狱（随后两人都被赦免）。

埃利奥特于2018年向ICSID提起诉讼，声称政府的行为违反了与美国的自由贸易协定，并寻求7.7亿美元的赔偿。政府声称，Elliott 的对冲策略包括在合并完成后购买 Cheil 互换，这意味着 Elliott 获得了 190 万美元的利润。尽管法院做出了对其有利的裁决，但 Elliott 表示，其仅获得 1.08 亿美元赔偿，其中包括利息和法律费用。

6 月 27 日，司法部并没有悄悄偿还，而是请求法院从三星之前向 Elliott 支付的与合并相关的款项中扣除。继续让外国投资者的日子不好过，似乎与该国资本市场改革的精神背道而驰，该国资本市场改革的目的是吸引投资者并结束困扰该国企业的“韩国折扣”。这种干预——在其他正在进行的案件中，政府被指控对外国公司的业务交易施加不当影响——在一定程度上解释了折扣的原因。

整个事件也可能让普通韩国民众感到不安。除了法庭案件导致公共资金流失之外，据一些估计，最初的合并使该国养老基金的价值减少了 3 亿美元。首尔国立大学的朴相仁表示，这部剧凸显了“政府与财阀之间的关系将如何让纳税人付出代价”。 ■

克里斯蒂安·布鲁赫总是表示西门子能源的扭亏为盈并不容易，但“这次挫折比我想象的要严重”。 6月23日，在公司放弃全年利润指引后，工程巨头西门子天然气和电力业务于2020年分拆出来的西门子能源公司老板在与分析师的电话会议上表示，“太多了”。已被扫到地毯下”。他承认，其风力涡轮机制造商西门子歌美飒今年将出现巨额亏损，并且需要比预期更长的时间才能实现盈利。

西门子能源公司（Siemens Energy）拥有 92,000 名员工，去年销售额达 300 亿欧元（合 328 亿美元），对此消息的反应非常激烈。其股价下跌超过三分之一（见图表），市值蒸发近 70 亿欧元。 “市场反应如此强烈，因为布鲁赫先生无法判断问题有多严重以及解决这个问题需要花费多少钱，”联合投资基金经理费利克斯·施罗德表示。西门子能源表示，解决歌美飒的问题将花费“超过10亿欧元”；经纪公司杰富瑞 (Jefferies) 给出的估值为 20 亿欧元。

瑞士信贷银行的安德烈·库赫宁表示，西门子能源公司存在三组问题。一是西门子海上风电业务与西班牙歌美飒陆上业务在2017年联手后，整合管理不善。西门子能源直到最近才完全控制歌美飒，一直持有多数股权，部分原因是为了收购歌美飒。使涡轮机故障最终得到控制。

另一个原因是，歌美飒与其他风力涡轮机制造商一样，受到供应链中断、通货膨胀以及钢铁等零部件和原材料缺乏的严重打击。这增加了成本，但无法转嫁给客户。他们的合同早于这些通货膨胀趋势，并且不包括收取更高费用的条款。它还受到通用电气可再生能源公司、Nordex 和维斯塔斯等竞争对手的破坏性公开招标竞争的影响。第三类问题是歌美飒特有的，与陆上涡轮机的性能低于标准有关，特别是其叶片和轴承。

库赫宁表示，歌美飒的问题能否解决是个大问题。布鲁赫先生是从西门子能源公司的天然气业务空降而来的，他在该业务方面表现出色。但他的信誉现在受到威胁，因为他似乎严重低估了歌美飒的问题。令股东尤其不满的是，他去年 12 月斥资 40 亿欧元购买了歌美飒剩余股份，歌美飒目前正在拖累西门子能源公司的其他三个业务部门：天然气部门、提供电网技术的部门和工业流程脱碳技术制造商。

投资者正在紧张等待将于 8 月 7 日公布的下一季度业绩。他们希望公司届时能够更明确地说明风电业务的亏损范围。西门子能源拥有 1020 亿欧元的积压订单（其中歌美飒价值 170 亿欧元），其四大业务支柱中的三项均运行良好。库赫宁先生表示，在接下来的 6 到 12 个月内，歌美飒是否能够得到修复以及布鲁赫先生是否会继续留任将变得显而易见。 ■

在大片充斥的夏天，迪士尼可能会费尽心思收回据报道花费 2.95 亿美元制作《夺宝奇兵》第五部也是最后一部印第安纳琼斯电影《 命运的表盘》的费用，该电影将于 6 月 30 日在美国上映。但这部电影对于另一个行业的一家公司来说已经很受欢迎。 134 岁的伦敦制帽匠赫伯特·约翰逊 (Herbert Johnson) 正在应对某种软呢帽不断飙升的需求。

“这真是太棒了，”帽匠米歇尔·波耶-斯利曼 (Michelle Poyer-Sleeman) 说道，她设计了最新款 Poet 帽子，哈里森·福特 (Harrison Ford) 在 1981 年的《夺宝奇兵》中首次戴上这顶帽子。该公司不得不保留该产品。直到电影上映前几周才开始。但自去年六月以来，《命运诗人》已经使赫伯特·约翰逊的收入增长了七倍。车间里充斥着风扇、蒸汽和熨斗的声音，积压了 300 多份订单等待手工制作。

这种繁荣标志着该公司的急剧转变。 《突袭者》获得成功后，它在后续作品《末日神殿》（1984 年）和《最后的十字军东征》（1989 年）中为印地提供了帽子。但帽子戴法的低迷带来了困难。意大利的 Borsalino 等备受尊敬的帽子制造商破产了。 Herbert Johnson 被出售，并一度停止内部生产帽子。 2008 年，印第的第四部冒险片《水晶头骨王国》的制片人去了其他地方。

经过 2016 年的重新思考，该公司重新回归手工制作，并将重点放在 Poet 上，该产品如今占销售额的四分之三。互联网带来了新客户，其中许多是美国人（还有许多女性）。顾客要等待长达六个月的时间才能买到价值 495 英镑（630 美元）的兔子毛毡 Poet，该 Poet 还带有可选的“突袭者旋转”，即将表冠旋转 25 度，以匹配福特先生佩戴他的腕表时的活泼角度（据说是为了在特技表演期间保持打开状态）。该公司建议避免大雨和高温，并且只能逆时针刷牙。琼斯博士肯定会嗤之以鼻。

赫伯特·约翰逊 (Herbert Johnson) 旗下的拥有 273 年历史的奢侈品公司 Swaine 希望在其他银幕产品上取得成功。它出售一把价值 520 英镑的雨伞，是吉恩·凯利在《雨中曲》中旋转的那种雨伞，还有一个价值 3,200 英镑的詹姆斯·邦德在《来自俄罗斯的爱》中使用的手提箱（不包括隐藏的刀）。 3月，新旗舰店开业。波耶-斯利曼女士说，戴帽子正在卷土重来。她在《命运的表盘》首映式上发现了几位客户。她说，还有一个“回归质量的趋势”。人们想要持久的东西，“而我们正处于这个利基市场。” ■

; Thu, 29 Jun 2023 10:12:30 GMT /内容/m9r9arne80fdoiic084fu1silvsakv1n https://www.economist.com/business/2023/06/29/indiana-jones-and-the-fedora-boom Our early-adopters index examines how corporate America is deploying AI

科技股迎来了丰收年。尽管最近出现了波动，但以同等权重的篮子来衡量，五巨头——Alphabet、亚马逊、苹果、Meta 和微软——的股价自 1 月份以来已经上涨了 60%。一家大型芯片制造商英伟达 (Nvidia) 的股价上涨了两倍，另一家芯片制造商AMD (AMD ) 的股价几乎翻了一番。他们的市盈率（衡量市场认为一家公司相对于其利润的价值）是标准普尔500 指数中位公司的十倍。

激增的主要原因是人工智能（ AI ）的前景。自从 11 月推出人工智能聊天机器人 Chat gpt以来，投资者对新技术浪潮越来越兴奋它可以创建类似人类的内容，从诗歌、视频片段到代码行。这种“生成式人工智能”依赖于在互联网大块上进行训练的大型语言模型。许多人认为这项技术可以重塑整个行业，对商业和社会的影响与智能手机或云计算一样大。人们认为，能够充分利用该技术的公司将能够扩大利润率并获得市场份额。

企业老板煞费苦心地展示他们如何采用人工智能。 4 月 4 日，摩根大通老板 Jamie Dimon 表示，该银行拥有 600 名机器学习工程师，并已将人工智能应用于 300 多个不同的内部应用程序。礼来公司（Eli Lilly）的老板戴维·里克斯（David Ricks）表示，这家制药巨头有 100 多个使用人工智能的项目正在进行中。

公司案例研究仅揭示了部分情况。为了更广泛地了解哪些公司和行业正在采用人工智能， 《经济学人》研究了标准普尔500 指数中所有公司的数据。我们研究了五项指标：提及人工智能的已发布专利的比例；针对人工智能公司的风险投资（ VC ）活动；收购人工智能公司；引用人工智能的职位列表；并在财报电话会议上提到了该技​​术。由于其他类型的人工智能可以为业务带来好处，因此我们的分析捕获了所有人工智能的活动，而不仅仅是生成波。结果表明，即使在科技公司之外，人们对人工智能的兴趣也在快速增长。此外，明显的领先者和落后者已经出现。

人工智能专业知识似乎已经在传播（见图表）。研究公司 PredictLeads 表示，过去三年里，全球大约三分之二的公司发布了提及人工智能技能的招聘广告。在那些这样做的公司中，如今 5.3% 的职位空缺提到了人工智能，高于三年平均水平 2.5%。在某些行业，增长更为显着。在零售公司中，这一比例从 3% 跃升至 11%，而在芯片制造商中，这一比例从 9% 增至 19%。

斯坦福大学 Amit Seru 提供的数据显示，2020 年至 2022 年间，人工智能相关专利的注册数量呈上升趋势。另一家研究公司 PitchBook 得出的结论是，到 2023 年，标准普尔500 强公司约 25% 的风险交易涉及人工智能初创公司，高于 2021 年的 19%。同样是一家研究公司 GlobalData 发现，大约一半的接受审查的公司在 2023 年谈论了人工智能。 2021年以来的财报电话会议中，今年第一季度美国公司的财报电话会议中提到人工智能的次数比上一季度增加了一倍多。 2020 年至 2022 年间，大约一半的企业已获得与该技术相关的专利。

生成式人工智能的使用最终可能会比其他类型的人工智能更加普遍。这是因为它擅长执行许多对经营公司至关重要的任务。咨询公司麦肯锡的一份报告认为，生成式人工智能创造的预期价值的四分之三将来自四个业务职能——研发、软件工程、营销和客户服务。在某种程度上，所有这些业务都是大多数大企业的核心。此外，任何拥有用于指导员工的内部数据库的大公司都可以找到人工智能驱动的聊天机器人的用途。摩根士丹利银行正在构建一款人工智能助手，帮助其理财经理从庞大的内部数据库中找到并总结答案。石油服务公司SLB已经建立了一个类似的助手来帮助服务工程师。

虽然许多公司都在采用人工智能，但有些公司比其他公司更加热情。使用每个指标对所有公司进行排名，然后取平均值，就形成了一个简单的评分系统。高层人士似乎正在赢得投资者的支持。自年初以来，前100强的股价中位数上涨了11%；对于得分最低的五分之一，它根本没有移动。

毫不奇怪，硅谷占据了榜首。从广义上讲，标准普尔500 指数包含 82 家科技公司。其中近 50 家公司进入前 100 名。Nvidia 是得分最高的公司。 PredictLeads 的数据显示，过去三年其三分之一的职位列表都提到了人工智能。去年，该公司在财报电话会议中提到人工智能近 200 次，比任何其他公司都多。其他排名靠前的科技公司包括云计算巨头 Alphabet（第 3 位）、微软（第 12 位）和亚马逊（第 34 位）。 They sell access to a range of AI tools, from services that help train sophisticated models to software that allows the use of ai without having to write reams of code.

Beyond tech, two types of firms seem to be adopting ai the quickest. One is data-intensive industries, such as insurers, financial-services firms and pharmaceutical companies. They account for about a quarter of our top 100. These firms tend to have lots of structured datasets, such as loan books or patient files, which makes it easier to use AI , notes Ali Ghodsi of Databricks, a database firm. Around a tenth of JPMorgan Chase's current job listings mention AI . The firm recently filed a patent for Index gpt , an AI -infused chatbot that gives investment advice. Health-care firms like Gilead Sciences and Moderna use AI to discover new drugs. Others, such as Abbott and Align Technology, are building AI -powered medical devices. America's Food and Drug Administration approved 97 such machines last year, up from 26 in 2017.

A second group is industries that are already being disrupted by technology, including carmaking, telecoms, media and retail. Thirteen firms from these industries make the high-scoring 100, including Ford, General Motors and Tesla. The rise of electric vehicles and the prospect of self-driving cars has encouraged vehicle manufacturers to invest in technology. In March Ford established Latitude AI , a self-driving car subsidiary that might one day rival gm ’s Cruise. In April Elon Musk told analysts that Tesla was buying specialised AI chips and was “very focused” on improving their AI capabilities in an effort to improve his firm's self-driving efforts.

Retailers are using AI to bolster their core business. Nike, a sportswear giant, filed an application for a patent in 2021 for a system that can generate three-dimensional computer models of trainers. Christian Kleinerman of Snowflake, a database provider, notes that retailers are also taking advantage of the growth of e-commerce by collecting more data on customers. That allows more accurate targeting of marketing campaigns. Some may take personalisation a step further. In 2021 Procter & Gamble, a consumer-goods giant, applied for a patent for an AI -based system which analyses users' skin and hair conditions based on photos, and recommends products to treat them.

One source of variation in ai use across industries may be a result of the type of work undertaken. A working paper led by Andrea Eisfeldt of the University of California looked at how exposed firms are to ai . The researchers assessed which tasks took place in a firm and how well Chat gpt could perform them. The most exposed were tech firms, largely because AI chatbots are good at coding. Those industries least exposed, such as agriculture and construction, tended to rely on manual labour.

Clear leaders and laggards are emerging within industries, too. About 70 firms in the s&p 500 show no sign on any of our metrics of focusing on AI . That includes firms in AI- heavy industries, such as insurers. The mass of smaller firms not included in the s&p 500 may be even less keen. One distinguishing factor within industries may be investment. For the top 100 firms in our ranking, the median r&d expenditure as a share of revenue was 11%. For those in the lowest 100 it was zero.

Vlad Lukic of BCG , a consultancy, notes that there is even a lot of variation within companies. He recalls visiting two divisions of the same medium-sized multinational. One had no experience working with ai . The other was advanced; it had been using a pilot version of the technology from Open ai, the startup behind Chat GPT, for two years.

Among early adopters, many non-tech companies' AI use is growing more sophisticated. Mr Seru's data reveal that about 80 non-tech firms have had ai -related patents issued which were cited by another patent, suggesting that they have some technological value. Some 45 non-tech companies in the s&p 500 have recently placed ads which mention model training, including Boeing, United Health and State Street. That suggests they may be building their own models rather than using off-the-shelf technology from the likes of Open ai . The advantage of this approach is that it can produce more-accurate ai , giving a greater edge over rivals.

However, a shift to in-house training hints at one of the risks: security. In May Samsung discovered that staff had uploaded sensitive code to Chat gpt . The concern is that this information may be stored on external servers of the firms which run the models, such as Microsoft and Alphabet. Now Samsung is said to be training its own models. The firm also joined the growing list of companies that have banned or limited the use of Chat gpt , which includes Apple and JPMorgan Chase.

Other risks abound. Model-makers, including Open ai , are being sued for violating copyright laws over their use of internet data to train their models. Some large corporations think that they could be left liable if they use Open ai ’s technology. Moreover, models are prone to make up information. In one incident a New York lawyer used Chat gpt to write a motion. The chatbot included fictional case-law and the lawyer was fined by the court.

But all this must be weighed against the potential benefits, which could be vast. Waves of technology frequently turn industries on their head. As generative ai diffuses into the economy, it is not hard to imagine it doing the same thing. Mr Lukic says that the biggest risk for companies may be falling behind. Judged by the scramble in America Inc for all things AI , many bosses and investors would agree. ■

; Sun, 25 Jun 2023 18:49:27 GMT /content/r1isddhjpr0evh26fsrcagodbf3c9i81 https://www.economist.com/business/2023/06/25/our-early-adopters-index-examines-how-corporate-america-is-deploying-ai America’s plan to vet investments into China

R ules to police investment by American firms in China have acquired a phantom quality: always imminent, always delayed. In recent months the steady beat of debate on the topic has quickened to a drumroll. In March America's Treasury and Commerce Departments delivered reports on potential rules. The next month Jake Sullivan, President Joe Biden's security adviser, trailed the policy in a speech. An executive order from Mr Biden is expected to follow. America's allies are mulling similar restrictions. On June 20th the European Commission announced plans, albeit vague ones, to propose an initiative by the end of the year.

When Mr Biden's executive order does appear, it is likely to focus on investments in three “force-multiplying” technologies: advanced semiconductors, artificial intelligence ( AI ) and quantum computing. The exact permutation of prohibitions and notification requirements remains unclear, but the rules will affect only a sliver of American investments in Chinese firms, which were worth more than $1trn at the end of 2021. According to data from Rhodium Group, a research firm, American firms made $120bn of foreign direct investment in China and $62bn of venture-capital ( vc ) investment during the past decade (see chart).

Geopolitical brakes on American capital are not an entirely new idea. Some companies with ties to China's military are off-limits to investors and the CHIPS Act bars firms that receive its subsidies from making investments that could benefit China's semiconductor industry. Advocates say outbound-investment rules are a necessary extension to America's patchwork of trade restrictions: if export controls prevent Chinese firms from buying some dual-use technologies and inbound-investment screening stops them snapping up American firms that make them, American capital should not be allowed to fund the technology's development in China.

Placing limits on America's globetrotting investors comes with risks. One is writing over-broad rules which limit capital flows and burden investors without good reason. Paul Rosen, a Treasury official, said in May that the rules would focus on “investment dollars that come with know-how and expertise”. European leaders say restrictions are needed to prevent “know-how leaking”. But figuring out what sorts of investment are leaky is tricky. A tech giant hoping to expand its advanced-computing efforts in China would presumably fall foul of this standard, but the case of investment firms, and their ultimate investors, is less straightforward. A private-equity fund might acquire a company but offer no operational advantage, whereas a small vc investment could come with technical expertise worth protecting.

According to the Centre for Security and Emerging Technology, a think-tank, in 2015-21 American investors, including the vc arms of chipmakers Intel and Qualcomm, participated in funding rounds that accounted for 37% of the $110bn raised by Chinese AI companies. American pension funds' appetite for returns has made them beneficiaries of such investments. Consider GGV Capital, one of the most active American investors in Chinese AI companies, according to data from PitchBook. Our analysis of public disclosures suggests that six American pension funds and endowments with combined assets exceeding $600bn have committed around $2bn to ggv Capital's funds in the past decade.

The national-security risk presented by such investments is an open question. So is that of whether Chinese investors could in any case replace the funding if American investors were restricted. Some feel the Biden administration should provide firmer answers before it requires asset managers and pension funds, which are typically exposed to hundreds of global investment funds, to search for traces of Chinese tech companies in their portfolios.

Another danger is mission creep. Under Mr Biden, economic and national-security policy have become increasingly indistinguishable. Last year the president directed the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States ( CFIUS ), the American inbound-investment watchdog, which has seen its caseload explode in recent years, to consider wider factors including supply-chain resilience. Scrutinising outbound investments on the basis of broad standards of national interest could become unwieldy. Fears of a growing investment bureaucracy have led some to suggest using existing sanctions rules instead.

Though Mr Biden's initial policy on outbound investment is expected to be narrower than anything that could be called a “reverse- CFIUS ”, there is no shortage of hawks outside the White House who imagine outbound-investment screening as a tool for industrial policy. In 2021 a bipartisan group of congressmen introduced a bill to screen outbound investment broad enough to have affected more than 40% of American investment in China, according to Rhodium Group. Last month an updated version of the bill was released. It would establish restrictions on investments not just in advanced technology but in industries including carmaking and pharmaceuticals, and give the White House the authority to expand the list.

The proliferation of trade restrictions does not stop at America's borders. Some attribute the delay in Mr Biden's executive order to trouble gathering support for new rules among allied countries. The Group of Seven ( G 7) jamboree of world leaders came and went in May with only a milquetoast commitment on the issue. Few countries globally place any restrictions on outbound investment, but screening of inbound investment is increasing rapidly. Europe is beefing up its protections: 18 of the EU ’s 27 members have such rules, covering an increasingly diverse list of “strategic” sectors. The commission's plans for outbound-investment rules threaten a growing tangle of red tape.

The effect on Western investment in China depends on the eventual scope of any rules. American investment is already falling. vc flows to China have plummeted by more than 80% since their peak in 2018. As the business environment in China worsens, there is no sign of a reversal. This month Sequoia, a big American vc firm, announced that it would split off its Chinese business by 2024. For now, hawkish policymakers can rest assured that China is doing their job for them. ■

; Thu, 22 Jun 2023 13:46:56 GMT /content/cbrj2klfvgrspcl2rahlfa4fp1r2r72v https://www.economist.com/business/2023/06/22/americas-plan-to-vet-investments-into-china Why is China blocking graphite exports to Sweden?

I N EARLY 2020 Swedish battery-makers noticed something alarming. Their Chinese suppliers were no longer able to sell them graphite, a mineral crucial to the production of lithium-ion cells. The Swedes assumed the problem would pass. Yet three years on, as Chinese investments in the battery industry have surged in Europe, Swedish firms are still largely cut off. In 2020 China's exports to Sweden of two types of graphite nearly disappeared. In 2021 and 2022 they vanished completely.

Although China's commerce ministry has issued no formal ban, many Chinese graphite exporters face a prohibition in all but name. One company was told that licences to export graphite to Sweden were no longer being issued by Chinese regulators. Given that China supplies more than 60% of the world's natural graphite and almost all the man-made version, the situation alarms producers that rely on China for the graphite anodes used in their cells. A halt in supplies from China can upset supply chains, raise costs and disrupt production. For Sweden, where the industry is just getting off the ground, a total ban on exports could do serious damage. In its only official statement on the matter, the European Commission said earlier this year that the drying up of Chinese graphite exports “is creating negative repercussions for battery production in Europe, a key sector for the eu green transition”.

China frequently throws its weight around when it seeks to punish countries over political disputes. In a row with Australia that started in 2020, it officially banned imports of coal from down under (the restriction was lifted this year) and put in place an unofficial ban on lobsters, with devastating consequences for Australian sellers who had come to rely almost exclusively on Chinese appetites. Officials in China have often threatened to ban exports of minerals such as rare earths to America as retaliation for sanctions. Export bans for battery minerals such as lithium and cobalt have become more common. According to the OECD , a club mostly of rich countries, China was the greatest offender in restricting the supply of materials needed for the transition to renewable energy.

Grasping the reasons behind the Swedish graphite ban could be just as important as dealing with it. At first blush, the ban appears to have been triggered by one of many small diplomatic spats between China and Sweden in recent years. In late 2019 Swedish PEN , a free-speech advocacy group, gave an award to Gui Minhai, a publisher and dissident who is imprisoned in China. The Chinese embassy in Stockholm immediately lashed out with threats against Sweden. Mr Gui, a Swedish citizen, has been at the centre of a dispute between the two countries since he was kidnapped by Chinese agents in Thailand in 2015. In 2020 and 2021 people familiar with Mr Gui's case believed it was the motive for the graphite restrictions. The same people now believe there could be more to it than a petty quarrel over an award.

As graphite exports to Sweden have slumped, China's overall battery and electric-vehicle investments across Europe have soared. In Hungary China's top battery-maker, CATL , poured $8bn into a factory last year, which amounted to one of the biggest foreign investments ever made in the country. In Poland smaller but similar factories are being built by Chinese firms. At the same time, graphite exports to those two countries have rocketed. Hungary imported more than $230m-worth of one form of graphite in 2022, up from just a few thousand dollars' worth of the stuff five years earlier.

As it happens, one of the most competitive firms in Europe's nascent battery business is Northvolt of Sweden. The company has begun to expand in Europe and will receive subsidies to build new factories. It is unclear what impact, if any, the graphite ban has had on Northvolt. But it is believed to have the potential to raise costs at a time when competition to win market share is fiercer than ever. The insiders aware of the Chinese graphite ban have started to question if the unofficial measures have been designed to stymie innovation in Europe as China builds a foothold there. In May one Chinese firm, Putailai, announced a $1.3bn investment to build Europe's largest factory for making anodes. It will become a core supplier to the Swedish battery industry. ■

; Thu, 22 Jun 2023 13:46:55 GMT /content/u1v6a1091679lbu47rcfbbpr1a15a0to https://www.economist.com/business/2023/06/22/why-is-china-blocking-graphite-exports-to-sweden Europe’s last finishing school targets anxious executives

T he three-martini lunch may be over, but the business dinner is here to stay—and it is a prospect that fills some executives with horror. For those who find the multiple rows of cutlery and wine glasses baffling, or who keep forgetting which side-plate is theirs, help is on hand to decode the hidden rules of etiquette. On the hills overlooking Lake Geneva, a company offers executives an extra layer of social polish to boost their confidence—and, perhaps, their career.

Established in 1954, the Institut Villa Pierrefeu, perched above Montreux, is the last finishing school in Europe. Its courses, which range from one to six weeks, cover everything from seating precedence and tea-service protocol to black-belt-level etiquette challenges such as eating a banana with a knife and fork. Historically, most of its students were young women preparing for the marriage market. Today, as social codes relax and demand for such an education wanes, Villa Pierrefeu is exploring a new pool of clients: business executives. Viviane Néri, the Institut's principal, says it is no longer a finishing school but a “starting school”.

A five-day course in the “European art of dining” (which costs around SFr5,000, or $5,570) features modules on menu planning, English-style table setting and French-style table manners. The students carefully taking notes on wine pairing and cutlery arrangement work in fields such as technology, corporate law and banking. Some are there to master a foreign culture. Ahmed Aftab Naqvi, the head of an advertising network in India, says that a spell at Villa Pierrefeu has helped him to “understand the diversity of cultures, customs, traditions and etiquette”. Others hope that their refined manners will command respect from colleagues. “I wanted to be elevated,” says one employee of a tech giant based in California.

Some lessons have not changed in years. Students are instructed that, once a meal is over, they can place their linen napkin on the right (French style) or the left (English style). But in other ways the school has had to adapt. Ms Néri has changed courses to suit professionals, scrapping the old nine-month diploma and offering classes all year round which clients can attend on their annual leave. Schools which failed to adapt have had to close, or take on less glamorous roles. Le Manoir, a former finishing school in Lausanne, these days serves as the international headquarters of Tetra Pak. ■

; Thu, 22 Jun 2023 13:46:55 GMT /content/bqtjv09qi06sqas1mr16298pb21d97bk https://www.economist.com/business/2023/06/22/europes-last-finishing-school-targets-anxious-executives India leads a boom in orders for passenger jets

T raditions abound at the annual airshow that rotates between Paris and Farnborough. One is visitors' observation that a glittering capital city, with the Eiffel Tower visible through the haze at the end of the runway, is preferable to a British town so unremarkable that its main attraction is its biennial airshow. Another is complaints about the heat from those trudging airstrips covered in commercial jets, fighter planes, helicopters and other pieces of high-tech kit.

The most predictable convention is that Airbus, a European aerospace giant, will take the opportunity while on home tarmac to deliver a blow to Boeing, its American rival in the duopoly supplying the world's big passenger jets. On June 19th it did not disappoint. Amid a slew of smaller deals, the most eye-catching was a whopper from IndiGo, an Indian low-cost carrier. Its order for 500 narrow-body jets from Airbus's A 320 family, to be delivered in 2030-35, is the biggest ever struck. Boeing's only significant riposte was to confirm an order made in February by Air India for 190 of its competing 737 max s and 30 of its wide-body long-haul jets.

If Boeing was disheartened, Darren Hulst, its boss of commercial marketing, did not show it. The orders unveiled in Paris are part of a rush by airlines to expand their fleets, in order to cope with a resumption of rapid growth in air travel as the pandemic recedes. Mr Hulst noted that Boeing's order book swelled by over 1,100 planes in the ten months following last year's Farnborough show, and that the world's airlines would require 42,600 new planes by 2042.

Carriers are clamouring for new metal. The combined backlog at Boeing and Airbus is around 12,000 planes. Air India wants almost as many as IndiGo; it confirmed in Paris that it would buy 250 Airbus jets. In May Ryanair, Europe's biggest airline, ordered 300 737 max s. Late last year United, an American carrier, ordered 200 jets, split between Airbus and Boeing. At the Paris show, Riyadh Air displayed a Boeing 787 painted in a striking purple livery. The new airline, financed by Saudi Arabia's sovereign-wealth fund, has ordered 39 of Boeing's popular wide-body jets, with a view to starting operations in 2025. Using the Saudi capital as a base, it aims to open up the country to international tourism. It is expected to place a huge order for short-haul planes soon.

Amid the bonanza, questions remain. First, can Airbus and Boeing increase production, laid low during covid-19, to meet demand? Airbus, which saw delivery rates of its A 320s sink to 40 a month during the pandemic, aims to deliver 75 a month by 2025. Ramping up supply chains will not be easy, especially as many firms laid off their costliest and most experienced staff.

Another question lingers over India. Demand there is soaring, as the world's most populous country gets richer. South Asia, where India accounts for 90% of the traffic, will be the world's fastest-growing air-travel market over the next two decades, according to Boeing. Whereas China has a fleet of 4,000 planes, India's fleet numbers just 700. IndiGo, which operates around 300 of them, has 1,330 more coming, to serve what has already become the third-largest domestic aviation market in the world.

Yet the rapid expansion of IndiGo, which controls around 60% of the domestic market, has come at a cost. Its latest fiscal year was the fourth in a row to end with losses. Part of its success is down to the failure of other Indian carriers. One competitor, Jet Airways, went bankrupt in 2019 and another, Go First, collapsed last month. Their grounding should enable surviving operators to increase ticket prices, but officials have been clear that such rises must be constrained.

A consequence is that underlying the excitement around the colossal new orders are concerns about whether some buyers will stay aloft. Another airshow tradition is for pundits to suck air through their teeth and wonder if the future is really as rosy as the numbers suggest. ■
